title: Why be rude to those stilllearning?
body: I fail to understand why some people feel they have to insult new players and call them noobs when they are playing in the introductory level of the bot games. if you arent a noob you shouldnt be in there surely. If you want to play in that area accept that it is supposed to be for those who are still learning the game so keep your mouths shut and put up with mistakes instead of insulting those who are genuinely tying to learn the game. It's behaviour  like that which gives games like this a bad name.

I'm not saying people should be reported for saying something like "Can you play safe now that your lane is ahead from the early kill you gave them? In that match up once they get a lead you'll lose every fight, just try and not die and get some farm so we can turn it around in team fights since everyone else on our team is winning." Hell even shorter less polite versions of that would be fine, but "God damn it, stop fucking feeding and let me carry your shitty ass you fucking noob. You shouldn't even be in my fucking elo, so stop making my game harder and just sit under your fucking tower and don't feed like the bitch you are." should not be considered acceptable and should rightfully be punished.

I never said I aggreed with him, which is why im a bit dissapointed I'm getting downvoted for it. I was just trying to clarify what I percieved to be his intentions to facilitate discussion. None of my opinions are present in this thread.

It's very possible both are true. In those specific games it could have been nothing of substance, but the community at large can still be shit. You need to look at it from a step back here.

From my own personal experience (That means mine, some have differences there,) bot games are the most toxic. I wanted to learn jungle back in season four, so I thought doing bot matches to start would save me from getting my head ripped off. As it turned out, even the thought of a jungler made at least two other grab smite and out-smite me easily (Since you know, they'd use smite together so it clearly was people queued together.) Game after game after game it kept happening, eventually forcing me to just do a normal where I got buttfucked. Worst part is that in the normal match I was told to uninstall like a piece of shit, where in the bot matches I was told to kill myself.

So there's a personal experience with it, which is why I believe this story happened. It most likely happened because from what I see the people that go in bot matches are the worst when it comes to how they act, at least for the most part.

I find that intermediate bots tends to be the place to go to learn mechanics or the basics of a role. You still get the occasional player who is just there to get their KDA as high as possible (nothing wrong with that, IMO, as long as they aren't toxic). I find most players to be civil, especially if you tell them "Hey, never played this champ/role, sorry if I suck". 99% of the time I get "Hey that's what bots are for" and in some cases, someone will actually know the champ/role in question really well and give me all sorts of build and strategy pointers.

I find that in beginner bots (which is where I used to go the first time I played a champ) you get quite a bit of toxic behavior.
He also assumed that the OP was male ... which is not in fact the case. In fact I am probably old enough to be his grandmother.

you're level 17, unless you have 20-30 minute wait times in your normals you're probably bronze skill level and still learning too. Don't be an ass for no reason. Either that or you're a jerk bc you aren't a weak player and you're leveling a new account bc you got banned for being a shitty human being.

Or ... Or ... choose a beginner or intermediate bot game instead of an intro one. Just a thought. if you're good enough to have to queue for normals and are maybe even Bronze level .. why do you need an intro game?

Anyway, what's even stupider is when people smurf and harass the people they are playing with or against for having a lack of skill or knowledge. What did you expect????

Personally if I'm playing a bot game, I'm only playing it to learn a new champion. There's a very good chance I SUCK with that champion. If I don't, then I LOVE when other people aren't amazing with their champions. Gives me more room for kills. I hate it more when I get a team of people who are amazing and the game ends in 10 minutes. I want a lengthy (~20min) bot game where I can get 15+ kills. If not games aren't to cushion your ego, what are they for?

i go bots to try champs, practice mechanics (i gotta learn azir, kalista's jumps, leblanc combo) or know my fps and ms

when i go to check my connection i really want a fast game

Do a custom game. 

You have no fear of your team ending early while you try out tricky combos,  can quit whenever you like at no penalty, and setting it up 3v1 intermediate is a good way to help you work on basic mechanics like csing under harass.

I didn't say we shouldn't report mean people. My meaning was that as we play, there will be bad encounters. Instead of taking it to heart, we should accept that people aren't always nice. 
What one is willing to accept and what to report is up to the individual, but if you go in taking offense at everything you don't find yourself agreeable with, not only will you stop enjoying yourself, but will also adopt a level of meanness comparable to those you'll seemingly come to despise.

To toughen up and be able to handle both criticism and unreasonable insults will improve your experience within the game by keeping you calm and reasonable enough to turn a bad situation into a positive thing.

I have no objection to criticism .. if done well and appropriately I learn from it ... the only problem with it is if you are doing it to complete beginners ... ones like me who grew up when computers still needed punch cards or full aircon room to run in ... they can be so distracted by it that they continue to mess up even more. 

It's hard enough to learn to move with a mouse instead of WADS and to find that you keep shooting off an ability instead of moving when you automatically press W. 

On top of that You have to to learn all the foreign language that goes with the game ... my first few games I was like WTF is bot?  I ended up going on to YouTube and watching some tutorial vids just so I could understand what people were saying.

It's not that I am upset about it .. I am angry about it because people who actually know the game shouldn't be playing in beginner bot games .. if they are then they should accept that others may still be learning the game .. that is what beginner bot games are for. I have only been playing for 3 days .. I need to learn ... if other people don't like that then they should go and play on a match that is appropriate to their skill level. If I mess up their game or score because I am still learning .. too bad ... I am doing the right thing by sticking with the lowest level of bot game to learn to control a champion and learn the game mechanics. The only thing insulting me or shouting at me does is distract me from what I should be doing so I make even more mistakes and stuff your game up even worse.

I think this stems from the nature of anonymity on the internet.  There's no identification for a player other than their summoner name, so they feel safe in harassing others verbally.  It seems as though the people who are extremely rude towards others have some desire to be a complete dick to another person without (immediate) repercussions, and as such they use this game as an outlet for it.

Fortunately the majority of people aren't complete ass-hats, hell some people are pretty cool here.  It sucks that it's the negative voices that speak the loudest though.
he is so right, he is not a cry baby, this is so annoying

I'm sorry you have to deal with this.  I love this game, it hits the sweet spot between Dota 2 (which is really intense on their mechanics) and HotS (which is a VERY casual game in general).  Just enough ability spam without making it excessive, and enough mechanic depth to make it interesting without having to memorize all the stats.  What is making me almost drop this game over others is the community.  Not the boards so much as the random people in games.  

The problem you bring up, I've encountered in every tier of game, from basic bot matches to my admittedly low silver 5 ranked games.  The ragers who take out their frustration on you, the people who just feed, the botters who don't actually play the game but have the computer do it for them.  These problems you will have throughout your League career, which is discouraging.  The only way I've actually started to enjoy the game again is by having people that you know to game with.  It's actually best if you use a voice chat with friends, I've had the most fun in this game with a 5 man with us all in voice chat and just joking around, while calling out things that matter in game.  The next best thing I would have to say is find a community that has a bunch of like minded people, and game only with them.  It's horrible that this is the way with this game, but it's the nature of this community.

Welcome to the game, sorry for the dregs. I've been around since the start of Season 2 (we're almost into 6 now), and I barely touched Normals until I reached 1000 Intermediate Bots games. Once I did however, I found I was well above what others expected a "fresh-faced, first time PvPing noob" to be. I spent most of my game time up to that point focusing on my teammates' plays, especially on champs I didn't know, along with a unhealthy love for LoL's Esports scene (I first learned about the game via the Season 1 World Championships).

My suggestion/advice?

Don't listen to the ragers. Report them after the match (the little red ! by their name in the post-game screen) and move on.

Watch some high-ranked and/or professional streamers on youtube or twitch (but not 'imaqtpie' and a few others, there's quite a few who just don't give a flying fudge most of the time). Bots is good for learning how to play a Champion or Role, but they don't teach you how to play against People. Only other People can teach you that. You've probably noticed it, but there's a box on the main game client where you can spectate high-ranked matches. I believe that is the single best thing Riot has done to help teach new players. Watch how they move, where they ward, how they set up for fights.

And never forget that it is Just A Game, =^.^=
